awd_titl_txt: Learning Physics in a Synergistic Scaffolded Programming Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12).  This project develops a Scaffolded Training Environment for Physics Programming (STEPP) in which students learn physics and cultivate Computational Thinking (CT) skills through state-based modeling by creating their own simulation tools. Finite State Machines (FSMs) are a method for state-based modeling and have been used to design algorithms and teach programming and engineering. The Unity game engine with Playmaker plug-in will serve as the platform for STEPP because of the low threshold for prior programming experience, the high ceiling for learning potentials, and the transferability to other applications. The project's hypothesis is that by constructing their own simulation tools, students learning in a scaffolded synergistic environment will master physics concepts and CT more successfully than students learning with pre-made simulation tools. The proposed research will provide new insights on how the use of dynamic modeling, implemented with cost-effective technology, can best help students understand physics concepts, develop CT, and improve their computing attitudes. By assessing improvements in understanding physics concepts, CT, and computing attitudes, this project will obtain information about relationships between these objectives which could indicate the advantage of synergistic learning.

Researchers will design and implement three Scaffolded Training Environment for Physics Programming (STEPP) modules with learning content that aligns with Texas's standards and the Next Generation of Science Standards. A summer institute will be held for inservice and pre-service teachers to learn and experience STEPP and incorporate it into their own curricula and assessments. The STEPP modules will be tested at a minimum of two high schools, with a minimum of 160 high school students and two physics teachers participating. Students' gain in physics knowledge will be measured by the Force Concept Inventory; their gain in CT, state-based modeling, and programming concepts will be assessed by rubrics developed in collaboration with high school teachers. Changes in students' attitudes towards computing will be measured by the Computing Attitudes Survey.

por.por_cntn:
For this STEM+C project, an integrative team of faculty and graduate/undergraduate students from the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) collaborated on development of a synergistic learning environment to help introductory physics students acquire physics concepts and computational thinking through formative experiences modeling and simulating kinematics using modeling tools based on Finite State Machines (FSMs). 

The project accomplished the following goals:

Goal 1. Develop an effective, accessible, scaffolded synergistic learning environment called the "Scaffolded Training Environment for Physics Programming (STEPP)," that assists students in learning physics concepts and computational thinking (CT) through building state-based models and dynamical simulations. 

Goal 2. Create three STEPP modules to help high school students to better understand 1D kinematics, 2D kinematics, and Newton's Laws of Motion. 

Goal 3. Conduct an experiment to assess the effectiveness of STEPP on students' gains in physics concepts and CT.

Goal 4. Test the relationships among students' gains in physics learning, CT, and attitudes toward computing. 

STEPP Environment and Modules (Goals 1 and 2). We sought portable, affordable, and readily available technology that would promote the adoption of STEPP in physics classes across the U.S. with ease-of-use and minimal cost. Using Unity game engine, we developed STEPP as an application running in a web browser on a laptop or desktop computer. The three STEPP learning modules focus on 1D/2D kinematics and Newton's Laws of Motion.

The use of FSMs, coupled with software-enabled scaffolding, allows STEPP to provide students with simulations that are physically accurate yet initially described by natural-language states in accord with their intuition. Scaffolding in the modules allows the student to understand physics concepts (e.g., acceleration and force) through increasingly detailed module designs. In each level of each module, students model physical systems as FSMs and see the resulting simulations displayed in a variety of representations: animations, graphs, vectors, free-body diagrams, numbers, and equations, all of which are displayed synchronously.

Field Testing (Goal 3). The original goal was to "Conduct an experiment to assess the effectiveness of the STEPP modules on students' gains in physics concepts and CT over and above comparable but conventional instruction methods." However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we decided not to assign the student participants to different experimental groups. We did not want to burden teacher/instructor participants by asking them to teach their courses in multiple teaching methods (i.e., conventional vs. STEPP) when they were already directed to switch teaching modalities (e.g., online, in-person, and mixed) with little preparation. Given social stresses during the pandemic and complications from variation in teaching modalities, we anticipated that data collected through online/mixed-modality high school physics courses would be messy. To address this, we added an additional field test using four sections of UTD's introductory physics course PHYS 1301, which was also held online during our field test. PHYS 1301 is equivalent to first-semester high school on-level physics and was easier to control in a field test. Among the PHYS 1301 student participants, 67.2% were Asian/Pacific Islander, 11.9% White/Caucasian, 7.6% Hispanic, 4% African American, 3.6% two or more races, 0.3% Native American, 2.4% Other, and 3% preferred not to answer.

Data Analysis (Goal 4). We tested the relationships among students' gains in physics learning (measured by the Force Concept Inventory), CT (measured by an instrument developed by the project team), and  attitudes toward computing (measured by the Computing Attitude Survey) by conducting a series of within subjects t-tests looking at change in our primary dependent measures over time. These analyses revealed that compared to pre-test, FCI and CAS scores were significantly higher, but CT scores declined. Follow up analyses indicated that CT scores improved for students who found STEPP easy to use but declined for those who did not. While useful for refinement of the STEPP modules, field testing in the height of the pandemic complicated data collection, forcing us to change the experimental design. We are hesitant at this time to draw strong conclusions on the efficacy of STEPP for simultaneous teaching of physics and CT.  

Outcomes

This project is the first (to the knowledge of the PIs) to incorporate state-based modeling into introductory physics education. The three STEPP learning modules are aligned with NGSS and Texas' standards and available to the public at https://stepp.utdallas.edu. The topics covered in these modules are commonly taught in introductory physics classes in high schools and universities across the U.S. and larger world. STEPP is a web application which requires no special software, hardware, or programming knowledge. Thus, STEPP can be easily and affordably deployed in other schools, including ones with higher rates of economically disadvantaged students.

The main features of STEPP, e.g. FSM-based modeling, software-enabled scaffolding, and multiple representations, can be replicated in many educational applications. STEPP has the potential to transform K-20 education by incorporating the synergistic learning of a STEM subject and computing into classroom education.
